text:
Hi Joel! Glad to have you.

I didn't get my first taste of programming until the 90's, which was high school for me. I have a deep appreciation for CS/programming history, though and I'm pretty interested in understanding more deeply what it was like before my time. When I was in college I got degrees in both CS and Art, and its an interesting contrast how much more emphasis art has on their history (its much older and wider, of course).

Still I think CS is perhaps the worst of all areas about studying and caring about their own history. And the industry is even worse, with the cult of the new and a memory of a goldfish.

Is there anything important that's been lost or forgotten along the way that you wish people would remember or recognize?

text:
Hi all. I was putting together some ideas and resources for the purpose of improving programming. I hope to find new ideas and share my thoughts here.

In particular I'm interested in language workbenches, structural editing, type systems, etc.
